column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=Consider the scenario illustrated in FIG. 17 In Release 1, a program's sources include a file directory 450 named/usr/src/project/include.
#Text=Two of the header files are xtr.h 452 and an architecture-specific header file in a subdirectory 454, vega/backup.h 460.
#Text=In Release 2, xtr.h disappears, having been merged into product.h 458.
#Text=In addition, backup.h 460 is made generic, and is moved up into usr/src/project/include 450.
#Text=The vega 454 subdirectory is deleted.
#Text=If, for example, however, while the programming staff is in the midst of Release 3 development, an important customer finds a critical bug in Release 1.
#Text=It is essential to be able to recompile and debug Release 1.
#Text=Traditional version-control systems have not had a graceful way to deal with the fact that file xtr.h 452 and subdirectory vega 454 no longer exist.
#Text=Their only recourse has been to replicate the source tree for Release 1.
#Text=This incurs a disk-space cost, and effectively destroys the relationship between a file in Release 1 and the same file in Release 2.
#Text=The version-control system of this invention solves this problem by capturing the source directory structure, and the changes to this structure, as versions of directory elements.
#Text=Each version of a directory element is analogous to a standard UNIX directory.
#Text=A UNIX directory is list of names, each of which has a pointer (i-number) to a file system object, a file, directory, and so on.

#Text=A version of a directory element of this invention is a list of names, each of which has a pointer to another object in the same VOB, a file element, a directory element, or a VOB symbolic link.
#Text=In many respect, directory elements resemble file elements.
#Text=In particular, each view provides transparent access to a selected version of each directory element.
#Text=Within the context of that view, the directory version behaves like a standard UNIX directory.
#Text=FIG. 18 shows that more than one name can be associated with the same element.
#Text=In this example, product.h and prd.h both correspond to the same file element 458).
#Text=Each such association of a name with an element is called a VOB hard link.
